docs.snippet: Three Salvadoran lawmakers and their driver were shot and their bodies burned in what may be a sign that the ghosts of the bitter Central American civil wars of the 1980s still linger....

docs.snippet: Who can pay attention to the Oscar battle between “The Queen” and “Dreamgirls” when you’ve got a political battle between a Queen and a Dreamboy?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Who can pay attention to the Oscar battle between “The Queen” and “Dreamgirls” when you’ve got a political battle between a Queen and a Dreamboy?

docs.snippet: Coming down to the wire, with no horse to ride....
docs.lead_paragraph: The polls close today as the Bagger struggled mightily -- actually, he just made a few phone calls, but that sounds too easy -- to bring some clarity to the Oscar race. With less than a week to go, it's hard to get all the frogs in one wheelbarrow and get them moving toward Sunday night.
docs.abstract: Coming down to the wire, with no horse to ride.

headline.main: Running Out of Matches in a Dark Place

docs.snippet: A foreign films primer for Academy members who haven't gotten around to seeing them....
docs.lead_paragraph: RiskyBiz points us to a foreign films Oscar primer in the Boston Herald. The paper should get a public service award, because the Bagger has discovered, after talking to quite a few members of the Academy, that most of them have seen only one or two of the movies.
docs.abstract: A foreign films primer for Academy members who haven't gotten around to seeing them.

docs.snippet: The Bagger thought he had friends; turned out they were all publicists....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mary McNamara at the Los Angeles Times pulls back the blankets on all of the Oscar campaigning. The Bagger recognized a lot of people he thought were his friends, but it turns out, they are paid to have lunch with him and talk up movies. Who knew?
docs.abstract: The Bagger thought he had friends; turned out they were all publicists.

docs.snippet: BASEBALL    National League  METS--Agreed to terms with C Sandy Alomar Jr. on a minor league contract.  SAN DIEGO PADRES--Purchased the contract of INF Oscar Robles from Mexico City of the Mexican League and signed him to a minor league contract. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BASEBALL National League METS--Agreed to terms with C Sandy Alomar Jr. on a minor league contract. SAN DIEGO PADRES--Purchased the contract of INF Oscar Robles from Mexico City of the Mexican League and signed him to a minor league contract. BASKETBALL N.B.A. MILWAUKEE BUCKS--Signed C Jared Reiner to a second 10-day contract. NBA Development League LOS ANGELES D-FENDERS--Signed G Daniel Horton and F-C Nick Lewis. Announced F Aloysius Anagonye left the team. W.N.B.A. CHICAGO SKY--Named Roger Reding assistant coach and director of player personnel. FOOTBALL N.F.L. CAROLINA PANTHERS--Released DE Al Wallace. CHICAGO BEARS--Announced Ron Rivera, defensive coordinator, will not return next season. Named Luke Butkus assistant offensive line coach. CINCINNATI BENGALS--Signed TE Greg Guenther to a two-year contract. DENVER BRONCOS--Signed LB Louis Green to a contract extension. GREEN BAY PACKERS--Signed LB Tim Goodwell, P David Lonie, CB Antonio Malone, LB Marcus Russell and DT Devarick Scandrett. INDIANAPOLIS COLTS--Designated DE Dwight Freeney as franchise player. MIAMI DOLPHINS--Named Terry Shea quarterbacks coach and Brad Ohrt assistant strength and conditioning coach. Signed P Ryan Flinn. SAN DIEGO CHARGERS--Named Norv Turner coach and signed him to a four-year contract, Ron Rivera linebackers coach and Ted Cottrell defensive coordinator and signed them to two-year contracts. TENNESSEE TITANS--Released OG Zach Piller. HOCKEY N.H.L. CAROLINA HURRICANES--Reassigned LW Ryan Bayda to Albany of the AHL. EDMONTON OILERS--Placed F Fernando Pisani on injured reserve. Recalled D Tom Gilbert and LW Jean-Francois Jacques from Wilkes-Barre/Scranton of the AHL. OTTAWA SENATORS--Recalled G Kelly Guard from Binghamton of the AHL. SAN JOSE SHARKS--Reassigned F Mathieu Darche and F Thomas Plihal to Worcester of the AHL.

docs.snippet: As the Bagger struggles toward his Oscar predictions, he turns to his faithful readers for help....
docs.lead_paragraph: No more fooling around. The Bagger is going old-school today, pounding the phones until the wires start to hum in search of the only thing anybody with proper priorities should care about this week: What will win best picture? Not what should. Not what would win a perfect world. Naw, the time for debating the relative merits of a film is giving way to its ability to attract votes.
docs.abstract: As the Bagger struggles toward his Oscar predictions, he turns to his faithful readers for help.

docs.snippet: Another award, another complication in predicting this year's best picture....
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar technicians were looking to the Eddie Award, the editing citation, to bring some clarity to best picture. So naturally, in a year where every event that is expected to resolve the story only thickens the plot, "Babel" and "The Departed" tied for the top spot. Whoa.
docs.abstract: Another award, another complication in predicting this year's best picture.

headline.main: Oh, That Totally Clears Things Up
